text: we're still talking about article 50 but
what is it and why does it matter in the
rule book of the European Union article
50 is the bit that sets out how a
country can leave and as we've seen that
is a pretty complicated process
now article 50 allows two years for
negotiations and the UK started the
clock in March 2017 the UK government in
the EU eventually reached a deal at the
end of last year that's their withdrawal
agreement basically the terms of the
divorce and a declaration on what the
future after brexit might look like but
the UK parliament rejected both parts of
this deal so Teresa may had to ask the
EU for more time article 50 can be
extended if all 28 EU countries agree
and that can happen more than once the
rules don't set any limits so we now
have a new deadline October the 31st but
if the extended article 50 period ends
with nothing still finalized then the UK
would leave the EU with no deal all the
laws that govern the relationship
between the UK and the EU would
disappear overnight
the other option is to revoke article 50
withdraw it all together that would
cancel brexit and mean the UK would
remain in the EU on the same term that
it has now the UK has the right to do
that on its own without the agreement of
other countries now supporters of brexit
say that would betray the referendum
results when seventeen point four
million people voted to leave but
critics say people now know far more
about what leaving the EU really means
and they deserve another say another
referendum and whether it all makes
sense and all the while the article 50
clock ticks on one day it will have to
stop but that won't be the end of
negotiations whatever article 50
eventually produces much of the future
relationship we'll still be up for grabs
and we'll be talking about it for
yes
[Music]
